events.summary: A federal judge, Beryl Howell, permanently struck down an executive order by Donald Trump that targeted the law firm Perkins Coie. events.summary: A Senate resolution aimed at repealing tariffs imposed by former President Donald Trump was blocked. events.summary: A federal judge ruled that Democrat Allison Riggs must be certified as the winner of a North Carolina state supreme court election, rejecting Republican Jefferson Griffin's challenge to over 60,000 votes. Griffin had argued that election officials wrongly counted these votes, mostly from Democratic-leaning counties. The judge, Richard Myers II, stated that changing election rules post-election and applying them retroactively to a select group of voters was unconstitutional. The ruling paused for seven days to allow Griffin to appeal, but it affirmed Riggs's victory by 734 votes after multiple recounts.

events.summary: Cliona Ward, an Irish woman and green card holder, was detained by US immigration authorities at San Francisco airport on April 21 due to a criminal record from nearly 20 years ago. events.summary: On May 9, 2025, President Donald Trump issued an executive order aimed at reducing overcriminalization in federal regulations. The order directs federal agencies to reassess and report on criminal regulatory offenses, emphasizing the disfavor of strict liability offenses and encouraging civil enforcement over criminal prosecution. Agencies are required to publish reports on criminal regulatory offenses and consider mens rea standards. The order seeks to prevent individuals from being criminalized for unknowingly violating complex regulations, aiming to ease the regulatory burden on citizens and promote transparency in regulatory enforcement.
events.title: Executive Order on Fighting Overcriminalization in Federal Regulations
events.why_relevant: This executive order addresses the balance between regulation and individual rights, aiming to prevent the misuse of regulatory power and protect citizens from unjust criminalization.

events.summary: On May 9, 2025, President Donald Trump issued an executive order aimed at increasing efficiency at the Office of the Federal Register. The order directs the Archivist of the United States to work with the Government Publishing Office to reduce publication delays and modernize systems. It mandates a review of publication fees to ensure they reflect actual costs and efficiencies. The order requires reports on publication times and fee schedules to be submitted to the Office of Management and Budget, with the goal of supporting the administration's deregulatory agenda by streamlining the publication process.
events.title: Executive Order to Increase Efficiency at the Office of the Federal Register

events.summary: Indiana Governor Mike Braun signed a new law that threatens to strip non-profit hospitals of their tax-exempt status if they continue to charge high prices. This legislation, the first of its kind in the U.S., was prompted by public outcry following a Guardian investigation into high prices charged by a major Indiana non-profit hospital system. The law mandates the Indiana office of management and budget to establish a price benchmark for non-profit hospitals, which must comply by 2029. The law aims to reduce healthcare costs and could lead to significant price reductions for hospitals like Parkview Health.
events.title: Indiana passes law threatening non-profit status of expensive hospitals
events.why_relevant: This law represents a significant state-level intervention in healthcare pricing, potentially setting a precedent for other states to follow.
